item.title: Satisfactory meets Genshin Impact in Arknights: Endield, whose second beta test sign ups are open now
item.content:encoded:
I'm having a hard time wrapping my head around Arknights: Endfield. It is One Of Those Games, to which there are two versions of. Arknights: Endfield is One Of Those Games, as in an anime gacha game filled with anthro-adjacent women for you to roll for and fight with in flashy, lackluster-in-feeling combat. Arknights: Endfield is also One Of Those Games, a factory sim where you build complex systems to produce, uh, something. This is a combination I cannot fathom, but registration for its next beta test is open, so perhaps I can figure it out.

Signing up to the test is pretty simple, you just need to head to the official website, fill out a little survey, and at some point you might be told you're in. No guarantees there, but if you're curious about playing it, there's no real risk involved. This is actually the second beta test for the game, and according to the press release, it'll be a bit different from the first one.

For starters, the story has apparently received a complete rework, from new cutscenes and dialogue, to choices that you can make that "lead to unique outcomes." There's a new region called Wuling to explore too, a "region that blends Eastern aesthetics with futuristic elements, combining traditional with contemporary."

The test includes nine new operators to try out, and combat has had a bit of a refresh too, with some new skills, tweaked abilities, and updated bosses. There is, of course, that whole factory system to try out too, and controls and visuals across the whole game have apparently been "enhanced."

Again, it feels slightly odd for it Arknights: Endfield to essentially be two games in one. I understand the original has some strategy roots, so it feels like a factory sim feels like it might be appealing to a similar kind of crowd, there's just an awkwardness to it. I wonder how the game will reckon with its sense of self because of those stark differences. There's no release date for the game just yet, so we'll have to wait to find out I suppose.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/satisfactory-meets-genshin-impact-in-arknights-endield-whose-second-beta-test-sign-ups-are-open-now

item.title: Frostpunk 2's first bit of DLC gets a seasonally appropriate release date, though it does sound a bit bare-bones
item.content:encoded:
I know that with winter on the way, you might be wanting to play some summery games to remind you of what life was like before Jack Frost started nipping at your chestnuts. Put that to the side, perhaps, just for a while, as developer 11 bit studios have revealed the release date for Frostpunk 2's first bit of DLC, Fractured Utopias.

Said release date is, quite appropriate for the season, December 8th, so a little over a month away. If you already own Frostpunk 2 and fancy giving it a go before it launches, you can actually sign up to try it out right here. The beta test for it kicked off yesterday, and is only meant to last a few days, so there's a chance you're too late, but there's never any harm in putting your name down on a waitlist. Fact!

Anyway, how about some Fractured Utopias details. According to the game's Steam page, it's all about embracing the "core concept of Utopia Builder mode." How that manifests is apparently by giving it more structure, as well as giving the choices you make a greater sense of weight.

Every faction in the game will be able to build towards its own idea of what a utopia is, complete with new systems, tools, and even a new endgame. There'll be 12 unique unlocks like laws, HUBs, and abilities per faction, and eight new faction hubs in total. On top of that, there's eight new faction-specific variants of the housing district, over 100 new narrative events, a couple premium tales, and to top it all off, a new map.

Is any of that worth paying for? Maybe! The base game's been a bit iffy so far judging by the word on the street, and this DLC does sound a bit bare-bones. Guess we'll find out in December! At least the base game is 40% off on Steam, if you fancy giving it a pop anyway.



https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/frostpunk-2s-first-bit-of-dlc-gets-a-seasonally-appropriate-release-date-though-it-does-sound-a-bit-bare-bones
